title: Understanding Spontaneity with Gibbs Free Energy
text:
A reaction is spontaneous if the change in Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG) is negative. The equation to calculate ΔG is:

$$ΔG=\Delta H-T \Delta S$$

where ΔH is the change in enthalpy, T is the temperature in Kelvin, and ΔS is the change in entropy. Use this to analyze the reaction.

title: Calculate Temperature for Spontaneity
text: To find the temperature at which the reaction becomes spontaneous, set $$ΔG=0$$ and solve $$-114000-T \left(-146\right)$$ for T. Consider the units: ΔH is in $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ and ΔS is in $$\frac{J}{mol·K}$$.

title: Solve for Temperature (T)
text: Using the equation $$0=-114000-T \left(-146\right)$$, solve for T.

title: Understanding Temperature Range for Spontaneity
text: Once you have solved for T, remember that the reaction is spontaneous when $$\Delta G<0$$, meaning T must be lower than the calculated value to ensure spontaneity.
